utterances: Let's go to Kristin(ph).
Kristin with us from Cedar Rapids.
Hello?
Hi, Kristin.
You're on the air.
Go ahead.
Yes.
I am somebody who I would describe as passionately pro-life, however I'm absolutely horrified about what's been done to Dr. Tiller.
And my concern out of this is that it will then become a tool or an excuse for people to argue over areas where maybe we have been able to find to meet more in the middle.
And where are those areas, do you think?
I think that there have been - I've been seeing an increase in at least in what I would call more polite dialogue.
This is such a polarizing subject, but we need to be able to talk about it and talk about it rationally.
And I don't know anything about the background of the individual who's committed this atrocity.
But I'm very afraid that people are going to use this as an excuse to express their angst or how they disagree as opposed to, again, trying to find common ground.
What - we've heard some advocates on both sides say - make abortion, well, more - less common.
Right.

I guess one of the main things that I, as somebody who is pro-life, gets frustrated with the whole abortion issue is many ways we focus so in on the act of abortion rather at focusing in on the reasons that women decide to get an abortion.
And if we address those issues as to why women are getting an abortion and why can't we make more options readily available in - show more support to women who find themselves pregnant unexpectedly.
I think that if we - the two sides can work together for that, we could maybe reduce the number of abortions that we have in this nation and avoid catastrophes like this.
Kristin, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
And Dion Lefler, thank you so much for your time today.
Oh, my pleasure.
Thank you.
Dion Lefler, reporter for the Wichita Eagle.
He joined us from his office there.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, how to build an earthquake-safe bridge between San Francisco and the East Bay.
rebuilding in New Orleans.
As the physical cleanup from Katrina continues, so does the effort to revive the city's legendary music scene.
It hurt when hometown heroes Art and Cyril Neville of The Neville Brothers said that they were moving out.
But a newcomer to the city, organist Robert Walter, is back and performing again, and reporter Molly Peterson has been listening.
(Soundbite of music)
Every New Orleans musician has a temple.
Robert Walter's is the Maple Leaf Bar.
It's not much to look at--dingy red walls, a bare light bulb in the ceiling fan--but sitting in the Maple Leaf now, Robert Walter remembers his first pilgrimage just after high school.
The Maple Leaf--I had read about James Booker playing here, and I was a big fan of James Booker's piano music, and so this was one of the places I wanted to see when I first came to New Orleans.
And I came down and I got to play on the piano at the set break.
I was just a beginning pianist at the time, but I was all psyched to be playing in, you know, James Booker's place.
(Soundbite of music)
Growing up in San Diego, Walter envied the oral tradition of New Orleans music, passed down through families and swapped around town night after night by performers in clubs.
And I liked sort of that plain-old, working-class jazz a lot of the time.
I thought those guys were sort of the unsung heroes.
Hold up ordinary things in the right light and you can realize their merit.
(Soundbite of music)
One of those working guys is Tim Green.
He plays tenor sax in more than a dozen bands around town.
It feels to me like he's conjuring up some emotions, both good and bad, and sort seems more like an exorcism of some kind of stuff inside him that comes out of the saxophone.
It doesn't sound like he's spitting back a bunch of technical vocabulary; it sounds emotional.
(Soundbite of music)
In San Diego, in his first band, Walter played organ with the Greyboy All-stars.
Their music, a blend of funk and jazz, revered the '60s organ records Walter bought in California thrift stores.
But for Walter, it began to lack feeling.

It was a very strict thing, the way--the kind of grooves that we were playing, you know, we thought of it as like scientific, almost, you know, and these things are allowed and these things are not, and--which eventually became sort of like a prison.
(Soundbite of music)
When Walter started looking past San Diego, he saw New Orleans.
He moved his family here last year, and on his new album called ""Super Heavy Organ,"" Walter asked New Orleanians to play with him.
Besides Green, he taps into a local sound with two drummers who alternate on the tracks.
Johnny Vidacovich is part of the contemporary jazz quartet the Astral Project.
He's more painterly, with cymbal flourishes above his drums.
(Soundbite of music)
And Stanton Moore plays with the funk band, Galactic.
Like Walter, he's young, so rap and rock influence his more aggressive style.
(Soundbite of ""Spell"")
This song, ""Spell,"" was an accident, a jam from recording.
It's a sign of Walter's growing confidence in playing in the moment.
Walter was on the road when Katrina hit, with Vidacovich and yet another city dweller, bass player James Singleton, and he'll tour more in the coming months than he planned.
But the destruction of New Orleans and its music economy has only strengthened Walter's commitment to the city's music ethos.
I think the real interesting stuff is in your frailties and your mistakes.
And when I see music, I want to know who the people really are, not sort of their idealized superself.
And if someone's compelling, they're compelling in all those ways.
(Soundbite of music)
Walter lives uptown right near the Maple Leaf Bar.
He was lucky; his house stayed mostly dry.
He had to clean out his refrigerator, of course--everyone did--but he's going to hold on to it and his adopted home, for a while.
To him, they're still new.
For NPR News, I'm Molly Peterson in New Orleans.
(Soundbite of music)
I'm Alex Chadwick.
More in a moment from DAY TO DAY.
President Trump is planning to issue an executive order tomorrow that he says will inject more competition into health insurance markets.
The goal is to make it easier for people and small businesses to band together and buy insurance, presumably at lower rates.
But the new policies they buy might not offer the benefits and protections consumers have become used to under the Affordable Care Act.
And, as NPR's Alison Kodjak reports, Trump's move could end up making insurance coverage cheaper for healthy people while driving prices much higher for those who need care.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Hi.
I'm Tracy.
Welcome to Farm Bureau Health Plans.
If you live in Nashville, you can get a health insurance policy from the Tennessee Farm Bureau for a hundred dollars a month.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

At least among kids who are sensitive or already prone to hyperactive behavior - now, some studies suggest that kids with ADHD may do better when they cut back on all processed foods, including ones with artificial food colors.
So Adesman says an important point here is that just removing artificial colors from candy bars does not turn them into health food.
They may be high in fat and high in sugar.
Two things that many kids may be better off eating less of.
Allison Aubrey, NPR News.
Pope Francis didn't exactly reverse the Catholic Church's long-held stance again contraception today, but in light of the rapid spread of the Zika virus, he appeared to make an exception.
